comments.commentBody:
If there are federal employees who could be making more money, including all of their perks, they would have left long ago. Federal employees are paid more than comparable workers in the private sector, plus they are paid overtime, which highly paid professionals in the private sector are not. And in the private sector, employees are accountable for their actions.

If you had read the article, you would know that the heat gets turned off at night.
Let's be clear; The conviction "went away" not because he was innocent, rather the victim became uncooperative and refused to testify after she received a payment in her civil suit.
Charges expunged, woman battered.  This is fine by you?
It feels a bit odd to change the outcome of your answer, by bringing in the notation of steroids.

"Two players on the Philadelphia Eagles, who played the Cowboys on Sunday, said they used “a little extra mustard” when blocking Hardy. “It’s a joke a guy like that is able to play this quickly,” Eagles center Jason Kelce said."

I wonder if Jason Kelce and the other wanna-be hero on the Eagles gave "a little extra mustard" to Riley Cooper, who went on an N-word rant against an African American security guard at a Kenny Chesney concert two summers ago?

As for Hardy, the guy has been vindicated by the legal system, folks harping on the "conviction" don't really understand the judicial process. Yes he was convicted, in the equivalent of Municipal Court, which is immediately appealable to the next level criminal court, which here in Pa. would be the Court of Common Pleas, in NY it would be the Supreme Court for the respective Borough. On appeal there's a new trial, with all the evidence being brought back into play and put under greater scrutiny by a more experienced judge (or even jury, as the case may be). At that new trial the alleged victim refused to testify. We may not like the outcome, but according to our judicial system the conviction went away. Thus the charges were rightly expunged.
I'm not positive, but I think that Washington, Adams and Jefferson lived in far more palatial quarters than these congressional offices.
Just because you get your news from the comedy channel doesn't make it a good source.  The Congressmen get plenty of exposure to real people back at home.
The Republican Party has offices where partisan activities and fundraising can be done legally.  That's why he's coming back to his office late at night.
Just because the term subsidiarity is over your head doesn't make Ryan intellectually stunted.

They're not getting housing stipends, but the taxpayer does reimburse them for their travel to and from home.

In all probability, they eat free most nights at receptions, and they have subsidized restaurants for breakfast, lunch, and those evenings they don't get a free meal.

Labor unions (organizations)  have been vilified since Reagan to the point of no return. The American people don't understand the correlation of the waning middle class and the destruction of our unions, thus this corporate treachery will continue, weakening our country further.

Thank you for your comment. I'm a Canadian doctoral student here in the US and I want to have the option of one day working here as a clinician, open a practice, hire staff and offer needed healthcare services. But this H1B business is discouraging and I've been dreading the day when my OPT year expires.

Obama had nothing to do with these rules. They were written and interpreted long before he came to office. Plus, were he to try to change any of the basics, the screaming would be heard from coast to coast and probably all of the Republicans on Capitol Hill would rise up and condemn him as someone who doesn't care about America's tech industry. They would probably find a way to accuse him of opposing jobs for Americans, too.

As for border jumpers, the Obama administration has deported more undocumented immigrants than G.W. Bush did, many more (look up the numbers).

The Obama admin. fudges the numbers. Illegal immigrants apprehended at the border who are turned back are now considered "deportation." That's where the increase comes from. The number of *true* deportations - of illegal immigrants already in this country - is way down. From the LA Times:

Expulsions of people who are settled and working in the United States have fallen steadily since his first year in office, and are down more than 40% since 2009. On the other side of the ledger, the number of people deported at or near the border has gone up — primarily as a result of changing who gets counted in the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency's deportation statistics.
Obama may not have started it, but he has pushed to increase H1b visas in every immigration initiative he has had any part of.

When 1-2 million people have been crossing the southern border each year fo the last 20 years, nd most of them are allowed to stay, and then the large companies have the advantage for obtaining most of the 85,000 Visaa a year, then you know our President understands little about our economy or small business!

Inspector Renault is shocked. Shocked. Gaming the H1-B visa system? Who knew?

Other than people who have wondered for the past 30+ years about job advertisements with such highly specific requirements that they could not possibly apply to more than a handful of people who just happened to speak fluent French, have an advanced technical degree in a subject only given in Switzerland, who have at least two years experience as a patent examiner in a Scandinavian country.

I am all for bringing foreign workers to the US in all occupations, provided that the recruitment process is on the basis of bona fide requirements than simply as a way of getting residency status for someone an enterprise has already decided to hire.

But the whole process is, and always has been, a charade to get around the uncomfortable fact that political boundaries and labor markets are a total disconnect. That's why we have offshoring.

Yes, these are jobs that go to foreigners rather than to citizens. That's only a bad thing if they would otherwise go to citizen. If it's Mr. Pandey or the highway (because the job is, in essence, for a business partner), it's not going to go to a citizen instead. However, even if on a level playing field of real, non-pretextual job qualifications, including willingness to take a lower wage due to the other advantages of being in the US, it is still far preferable to lose a job to a foreigner who is here spending in the economy than to one who is there and not.
You think the lottery and FanDuel are the same?  Do you also think a rain shower and a typhoon are the same?  Your simplistic thinking is a problem.
The gambling that is associated with the NFL explains a pretty sizable portion of its TV popularity and this certainly predates these new gambling avenues.

The sponsorship of the NFL is most alarming here- a sport is about escape, recreation, diversion and teamwork- giving everyone a monied stake in the action is a sure way to corrupt the enterprise. Once everyone realizes that there are only a handful of winners and that some will wager the rent, we can see this for what it is --another arena for fools to hand their money to those who take us for suckers.
Gambling is for the mathematically challenged and we are very vulnerable to the dopamine rush and the power of intermittent reinforcement in these games- to have misleading ads promising something for nothing is the last thing we need permeating our culture. Let's get back to the game itself and allow it to entertain us without robbing us blind and adding more millions to a greedy NFL.

Dan, your multiple posts here border on the redundant and obnoxious. Try to relax a little, it's just a meaningless little gambling organization, no bearing on your life, and yet you seem to be more or less copy and pasting the same argument as a reply to every person. Strange for somebody who just doesn't care.

.
In more important matters pertaining to the photo:

1. Brett FAVRE did, indeed, start in a Jets-Vikings game. He played for the Vikings. He lost the game, and the Jets went as far as they have gone in an NFL season: They played in the AFC Championship Game.

2. Beginning in 1970, the Jets and the Vikings have played against each other in regular-season games 10 times. The Vikings win 2 games in Minnesota. The Jets won 3 games in Minnesota. The Jets won the other 5 games as well.

3. What uniform is the player in the background of the blog photo wearing? I don't know. I had hoped, of course, that it was a San Francisco FORTY NINER, but I think the socks are wrong. Better guess? Washington of the NFC East. But I really have no answer. Guidance welcomed. I've also excluded the Cardinals, because the red color does not look "Cardinal" to me. And most NFL teams as of 2008 had bizarre colors in their uniforms. Like "teal". Don't misunderstand; teal is a fine color for a swimming-pool inflatable raft perhaps. But for an NFL uniform? Green and white, black and silver: Those are colors.

4. I, too, have little use for Packers and Vikings.

5. Have the Jets and Vikings ever faced each other in preseason play? I don't know.

6. Have the Jets and Vikings ever faced each other in postseason play? Hahahahahahahaha: That could happen only if the Jets were AFC Champions. The Jets have never been AFC Champions.

.
JFC,

I was busy composing more tripe so did not see your Reply, which was posted 13 mins before my Reply.

You are more familiar with NFC uniforms, so I shan't take issue with you.

As you will see from the Reply I composed while yours was being posted, I say, "Better guess? Washington of the NFC East." Is this better than the word you used? Matter of opinion. Is it better than the word used in the caption? I would think so.

The Vikings are not even in the right NFC Division (nor the right part of the country).

The preseason Meadowlands game against the Washington team was FAVRE's first game as a Jet. He opened the scoring with a TD pass, but the Jets lost 13-10. The game would have received zero attention but for his debut.

The short sleeves are easily explained by the fact that even at 7 pm that evening, the temperature at the stadium was 80 degrees F.

Much more important was the Jets' 2010 victory over FAVRE and his Vikings in a nationally-televised Monday-night game!

As John correctly stated, the opposing team player in the background is unquestionably a Washington Redskin. The 'Skins' colors are burgundy and gold. Loyal and long-suffering Washington fans will instantly recognize the uniform, making out in this photo the almost subliminally visible traces of gold in the front-to-back stripes on the helmet, in the logo on the side of the helmet, and even in the stripes on the burgundy pants.

I'm pretty much with Mac Knight on the theme. It's not that I terribly mind themes—some can even be quite funny—it's just that if they don't easily suggest themselves, well, who needs 'em?

.
.
Atop the blog is a photo captioned, "Brett FAVRE warming up before a Jets-Vikings game." (capitalization on FAVRE added; period at the end of sentence fragment is SIC)

John from CHI and Wags from COL each made points about the photo (which, indeed, shows Brett FAVRE and other players in Jet uniforms performing what seem to be pre-game warmups). I disagree with both of them to a degree.

FAR MORE IMPORTANT, though, is that they missed the most egregious aspect of this sordid affair: The NFL Jets and the NFL Vikings have opposed one another in regular-season play (most recently) in 2014, 2010, 2006, and 2002. Brett FAVRE was not a Jet in any of those games. Sure, I looked into preseason games while FAVRE was a Jet, but I didn't have to.

The Jets did not play the Vikings in the 2008 preseason either, but it would be moot anyway, because there is a non-Jet player in frame. He seems to be wearing an NFL uniform and helmet. He IS NOT a Viking player. So the caption is wrong.

Doesn't that matter more than what uniform Brett FAVRE is wearing?

As for New York centrism, that has traditionally pertained to Manhattan and the Bronx. The NY Football Giants have played in both those boroughs. Queens County (where the Jets once played) did not become part of New York City until 1898 (along with the former City of Brooklyn).

But Brett FAVRE played for the Jets in New Jersey. Are New Jerseyans geocentric? I defer to John and Wags. But "NY Jet Brett FAVRE" did not play the Vikings.

Some gambling games involve skill -- certainly poker involves considerable skill -- other are pure random chance, like the roulette wheel.

It's all still gambling.

Jesse, it is not the annoying ads (though they ARE annoying AND deceptive) -- it's that it is clearly gambling and it clearly violates the rules to run this online (as opposed to in a state-regulated casino).

I seriously doubt they employ "thousands" in today's computerized workplace, where even Facebook runs with only hundreds of employees.

I think because ORIGINALLY fantasy sports was just played for fun, and the prizes were like $100 -- it wasn't high stakes gambling or anything you could go broke on, or bet your whole paycheck (leaving your family in poverty).

@P.S. if you read some of the comments in some forums you will note that some Indians actually believe the reason they are chosen for these jobs is because they are much more superior intelligence wise. I read some comments along this line about outsourcing from Australia. They are having similar issues. It's amazing that some of these people actually don't connect the dots and realize that they are hired because they are paid less than the native engineers not because they are intellectually superior.

My husband is a computer engineer who has spent the past 10 years working all over the country as a contractor and not by choice. He is currently working in Austin until December and then will be home unemployed again. I live in Portland Oregon so we see each other just once a weekend every three weeks or so. This is what engineering is like these days!  And we ask our best and brightest to major in engineering!<br/> Often my husband is the only American in the group--with less expensive engineers brought in mostly from India on HIB visas. These are not good engineers. These are cheap engineers. Often they have very little experience and graduate from engineering programs that would not even meet U.S. standards.  Even his Indian-American engineer friends that are U.S. citizens do not like this situation as they are constantly replaced with cheaper H1B visa engineers from their native country.  This is not about finding talent!

This is a completely ignorant response. The U.S. does much less business in India when compared to China or Westen Europe. Indians are terrified every time someone in Congress or the campaigns mentions the h1-B program, because many Indian middle-class families see it as a way to get their kids to the U.S. and away from India (less so now that India is doing better economically, but still largely the case).

The root cause of this is demand from US MNCs to reduce their costs. That's the dog that wags this tail.

Another scam. H1/L1 abuse is only a part of the whole picture. Actually, a lot of jobs, even Government IT jobs are getting outsourced to Indian IT workers! This how that scheme works, an real example ..
LCS got a "managed services contract" to manage the IT resources of "Burbank Water and Power", Burbank, CA. They take their cut and sub-contracted it to an Indian IT company in Houston, TX. The Indian IT company keep 1 person in US to interact with the clients and most of the work is done in India, probably for $10/hr! All these folks who work for the Indian IT company get a "phony" e-mail id of LCS as a cover up! LCS has contract from the State of CA, Utah, Ohio, Arizona etc and these middle-men companies rip off American IT workers. This abuse must be stopped. We should insist that the Government contracts must be done by the workers in USA. It should not be outsourced to workers in other countries. Anyhow, they are bringing in tons of them every year.
Our corrupt Politicians and greedy business are ruining this country!

@B from Hawaii
I guess a brain surgeon is only worth minimum wage if I can bring in someone from the third world to do his job for $7.25 an hour. I bet I could find a desperate person to do your job, too, for half of what you are paid now.

I believe it is the job of our leaders to protect American workers from being devastated by foreign competition, not sell us out, especially when it is being foisted on us by our own American businesses.

Zaslavsky

It is snark about the embarrassing OBVIOUSNESS but simultaneously accepting as fact "Mission Accomplished." Typical Bruni. It passes for independent thought. And, he says Rubio is disciplined.

If not, identify a substantive Bruni Criticism of Rubio on Commader in Chief issues. Social issues, yes, C in C no. And it is not as if there were a lack of opportunities.

Bruni is selling Rubio. http://bruni.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/03/11/you-will-be-hearing-a-lot-more...

The conservative hacks at the NYT have joined in the sell. He is the oligarchs and their fellow traveler rentiers best hope. He is hispanic you know...

"It was as if he'd come dressed in a T-shirt that said "Commander in Chief."

Sure, you can argue that this was over-the-top, tongue-in-cheek, hyperbole - of a complimentary nature, with a slight ribbing.

But it was *not* ridicule, *not* snark, and not meant in any way negative towards Rubio. More along the lines of the type of self-effacing humor one would direct towards oneself, or someone liked and identified with.

Bruni clearly favors Rubio, and the only negative line in the whole article was this single line:

"But he was scary, charting a course of unrestrained interventionism, and when he fielded a final question about how he’d stack up to Clinton, he reverted to talking points."
I agree EuroAm

"Rubio is not just smooth but clever and disciplined. Eager to live up to the buzz that he’s really the front-runner, and even more eager to put to rest the chatter that he’s too young and callow, he stood tallest and spoke most forcefully when talking about issues of global leadership. It was as if he’d come dressed in a T-shirt that said “Commander in Chief.”"

In case you missed it, Bruni, after his column based on the higher authority of his own pain at being misunderstood--can you imagine!--while shilling, again, for the young, dynamic, Rubio, wrote, I quote again as this is unbelievable, "It was as if he'd come dressed in a T- shirt that said “Commander in Chief.”

Ladies and gentlemen, an anointed NYT columnist addressing the debate among the republican candidates for President of the United States. A Very Serious Person at the height of his Very Serious Powers. I quote again because it is hilarious, hilarious that is once you give up on human kind and your own soul and just enjoy the farce: "It was as if he'd come dressed in a T-shirt that said "Commander in Chief."" Hehehehe.

He and his editors don't know any better? Hehehehe. They be swooning over the little guy. Hehehehe. The fix is 80% in as limited options constrain choices. T-shirt. Commander in Chief. Hehehehe. Gravitas baby!

.
.
Some numerical notes:

1. FORTY-NINE is more than the combined ages of the constructor of today's regular Crossword and the constructor of today's Mini Crossword.

2. Getting precisely FORTY-NINE of a given letter in the clues, and in the grid, is a mighty impressive feat.

3. Frankly, getting the same number of any given letter in the grid as in the clues would be an impressive feat, as long as that number is greater than 10.

4. My solve time for this puzzle was 3 seconds slower than my "personal best" Wednesday-crossword solve time. My solve time on the prior Crossword was 4 seconds slower than my "personal best" Tuesday-crossword solve time.

5. This is one of the best David Steinberg puzzles we've seen here in a while. It was pretty much a themeless, but it was a good puzzle. Good clues.
Yes, MTF, that fuzzy player in the background is a Redskin, but since Redskin is a word not allowed in the NYT, Vikings is a good substitute.
